Chapter 14: Equal Practice (Part 4) Chapter 14: Equal Practice, Part 14 (The text in the Dunhuang version does not have a chapter title) At that time, in the assembly there was a celestial being named AvatÄra, who said to the Buddha, World-Honored One!

Why is it so?
If one does not practice all dharmas, then one does not discriminate between right and wrong.

One who practices in this way does not practice good, does not practice evil, does not practice with outflows, does not practice without outflows, does not practice the mundane, does not practice the supramundane, does not practice the conditioned, does not practice the unconditioned, does not practice birth and death, does not practice nirvana - this is called following the Dharma.
If one gives rise to the notion of dharmas, then one is not called one who follows the Dharma.
If one thinks:
'I practice this Dharma,'
then that is idle speculation, not following the Dharma.
If one does not accept any dharmas, then one follows the Dharma.
Not recollecting, not discriminating, not practicing any dharmas - this is called following the Dharma.
At that time, the celestial son Irreversible said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
If one is able to follow the Dharma in this way, this person will ultimately never again engage in wrong practices.
Why is this?
Correct practice is called ultimate.
Those who abide in the wrong path have no practice in accordance with the Dharma, while those who abide in the right path have practice in accordance with the Dharma.
World-Honored One!
Those who practice the right way have no wrong Dharma.
Why is it so?
It is because all dharmas are equal and without distinction.
At that time, Brahma Heaven of Meaningful Thought said to the celestial son of irreversible progress:

He replied:
If the Dharma taught by the World-Honored One had two characteristics, I would practice in accordance with the Dharma;
But now, since the absence of two characteristics is itself practice in accordance with the Dharma, in it the practitioner and the practiced Dharma are both unobtainable.

I practice in accordance with the Dharma by means of the non-dual Dharma, because I am free from all discriminations. As the dharmas are practiced in accordance with suchness, this is called practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Meaningful Thought said:
